Nepal enters into lockdown at 6am; All public movement outside of the home, except to seek medical attention or purchase essential foodstuff, has been prohibited. Since essential trips are still allowed, this is coded as a 2G. https://web.archive.org/web/20200525213942/https://kathmandupost.com/national/2020/03/23/nepal-goes-under-lockdown-for-a-week-starting-6am-tuesday; https://web.archive.org/web/20200525214053/https://www.nepalitimes.com/banner/nepal-goes-into-lockdown-for-a-week/

Per the lockdown order all residents and visitors throughout Nepal are required to remain in their place of residence. All movement on the roads, by vehicle and on foot, is currently prohibited with very limited life safety exceptions. Since this effectively shuts down intra-country travel, coded as 2G; https://web.archive.org/web/20200525215040/https://np.usembassy.gov/health-alert-u-s-embassy-kathmandu-nepal/

Nepali government on Wednesday decided to open borders with China only for cross-border movement of essential goods, a senior of Nepali government said. He however said that border points would remain closed for the people's movement. Nepal has shut down all land border points for the movement of people amid COVID-19 threat. Since non-essential transfers and movement of people is banned, 4 is maintained as coding;  https://web.archive.org/web/20200525204825/http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2020-03/26/c_138916897.htm

The Nepal government will deposit the amount contributed by workers and employers of organisations affiliated to the Social Security Fund for the month of Chaitra. Employers can access the organisation-level welfare funds to make payments to their employees until the resumption of businesses. Migrant workers who returned from abroad and who could not go for work abroad despite securing work permit due to Covid-19 will be provided employment through the local level. The local level government are to collect the data of the people in the informal sector who need assistance. Those who need the assistance must go to their respective ward and submit their profile. With this, the local level government will provide the relief package (which includes daily essentials like food) to them during the period of the lockdown.; https://web.archive.org/web/20200526183014/https://kathmandupost.com/national/2020/03/30/these-are-the-relief-packages-introduced-by-the-government-following-extension-of-lockdown-for-another-week; https://web.archive.org/web/20200526181421/https://nepaleconomicforum.org/neftake/relief-packages-introduced-by-the-nepal-government-amidst-extension-of-the-lockdown/

Salt Trading Corporation and The Food Management and Trading Company Limited will be giving 10% off on the current prices for basic food items such as rice, flour, pulse, lentils, sugar, salt, oil, etc. Nepal Electricity Authority (NEA) will give 25% off for households on electricity up to 150 units. Nepal Telecom will give 25% off for their internet and data packages during the lockdown. Private schools (till secondary level) should exempt all fees, besides accommodation or boarding fees. The respective landlords should exempt housing rents for the workers in the informal sector. For the exempted rents, landlords will not have to pay the housing rental taxes. The government has extended deadlines for the tax filing by one and a half months. The value-added tax (VAT) and the income tax deadline has been extended till May 7.  The deadline to submit reports and other details to the office of Company Registrar (OCR) has been extended until May 13 for companies.  In case the expiration of driving license, route permits and others, the deadline has been extended to May 13, without any penalty or fines.  Those companies who have donated to the government’s “Corona Virus Control and Treatment Fund” can deduct such donations as expenses for the purpose of tax calculations.  The deadline to pay for electricity, drinking water, telephone and internet will be extended (with no fines) up until May 13.  There will be no custom duty for any government, private and community sector importing medical equipment.  Sugar mill owners must make complete payment to sugarcane farmers by May 13.  Extension of one month for procurement agreements done prior to the Covid-19 pandemic. Nepal Rastra Bank has instructed BFIs to extend the deadline for the repayment of monthly or quarterly installment of any loans by mid-July, which earlier was set for mid-April. Those borrowers who will pay the installments of their loans by mid-April will get a 10% waiver in their interest payment.;   https://web.archive.org/web/20200526181421/https://nepaleconomicforum.org/neftake/relief-packages-introduced-by-the-nepal-government-amidst-extension-of-the-lockdown/; https://web.archive.org/web/20200526183014/https://kathmandupost.com/national/2020/03/30/these-are-the-relief-packages-introduced-by-the-government-following-extension-of-lockdown-for-another-week

Free insurance of Rs 2.5 million for health professionals, including doctors, nurses, health technicians, health volunteers, cleaners, ambulance drivers, directly-involved security personnel, who are involved in the treatment and control of Covid-19 spread until July 15. Informal sector workers who have lost their jobs due to the ongoing crisis will be given the opportunity to participate in public-works projects for a subsistence wage or receive 25 percent of local daily wage should they choose not to participate. http://web.archive.org/web/20200526185502/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

The Nepal Rastra Bank (NRB) announced that banks will defer loan repayments due in April and May until mid-July. For working capital loans, banks will extend the repayment schedule of the amount due during the lockdown up to 60 days. Businesses in affected sectors, if they can show the needs, can qualify for additional working capital loans of up to 10 percent of the approved amount of their existing working capital loans, to be repaid within a year at most. The NRB directed banks to apply lower interest rates (up to 2 percentage points) when calculating the interest due for the period of mid-April to mid-July, applicable to borrowers from affected sectors. http://web.archive.org/web/20200526185502/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Social assistance will be strengthened by providing those most vulnerable with daily food rations, subsidizing utility bills for low-usage customers, extending tax-filing deadlines, and taking measures to partially compensate those in the formal sector for lost wages in the event of job loss. Measure announced April 26. Informal sector workers who have lost their jobs due to the ongoing crisis will be given the opportunity to participate in public-works projects for a subsistence wage or receive 25 percent of local daily wage should they choose not to participate.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201022092249/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

The NRB announced that banks will defer loan repayments due in April and May until mid-July. For working capital loans, banks will extend the repayment schedule of the amount due during the lockdown up to 60 days. Businesses in affected sectors, if they can show the needs, can qualify for additional working capital loans of up to 10 percent of the approved amount of their existing working capital loans, to be repaid within a year at most. The NRB directed banks to apply lower interest rates (up to 2 percentage points) when calculating the interest due for the period of mid-April to mid-July, applicable to borrowers from affected sectors.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201022092249/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
https://covid19.ndrrma.gov.np/.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201020230202/https://np.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/

The city has formed five teams for contact tracing for Kathmandu’s 32 wards. In an attempt to curb the spread of the virus prohibitory orders, and localized lockdown measures, have been imposed in all districts. Twenty-two points of entry along the India-Nepal border have been closed and all domestic and international flights have been suspended, with the exception of two weekly flights from the Indian capital of New Delhi.  https://archive.vn/z4xCQ

An article describes that several public awareness campaigns designed to break the transmission chain were issued through text, audio and video platforms such as newspapers, flyers, radio and television. Despite these efforts, the potential risk of coronavirus transmission at the community level "is not being taken seriously in Nepal".   https://archive.vn/CMJIb
Testing for those symptomatic. Testing and isolation for COVID-19 is limited to certain government hospitals, where services are basic.  https://archive.vn/aBsud

There have been some examples in some parts of the country e.g. the GoN has set up a system to screen individuals arriving in Kathmandu from other parts of the country or overseas by road or by air. Symptomatic passengers were taken directly to designated COVID hospitals and admitted, tested and treated appropriately. In contrast, asymptomatic passengers were kept in dedicated quarantine or advised to follow strict home quarantine and self-isolation and to avoid non-essential travel and community contact. Despite these regulations, there was no mechanism in place to monitor home quarantine and self-isolation.

Vaccinations efforts are focused on those aged 60 to 64. In mountainous districts, everyone above 18 years of age will be vaccinated given the availability of vaccines. Vaccines: AstraZeneca, Sinovac    As many as 691,494 people across the country have so far received both shots of the vaccine against the coronavirus disease as of 12 June. A total of 2,422,376 people have been administered the first jab of the vaccine as of 14 June. However, the government is struggling to procure enough vaccine doses. About 1.4 million elderly Nepalese received an initial dose of the AstraZeneca vaccine in March but now are unsure when they can get a second dose as the government struggles to acquire the vaccine. Additionally, COVAX, the UN-backed project to supply vaccines to poor regions of the world, pledged Nepal 2 million doses by March but has only provided 248,000 because it also is facing a serious shortage. Scant information exists regarding Nepalese schools reopening. Whilst documents can be found dating back to November 2020 detailing school reopening plans in the country, it seems these plans were not carried out. Information exists to suggest that schools are still restricted from opening, with no exceptions - see link for detail     [ https://web.archive.org/web/20210720223326/https://reliefweb.int/report/nepal/nepal-covid-19-response-situation-report-no-09-20-july-2021 ]

Details about exactly which sectors are closed are not readily available, however the link below suggests that certain sectors (farming, corn plantations, office work in some regions) are only just returning. The information also notes that only "Most markets and offices are open" which would suggest some areas remaining closed.    [ https://web.archive.org/web/20210720072326/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/DCA_SITREP%20July%2020.pdf ]

Restrictions are still in place to restrict large gatherings, see below    [ https://web.archive.org/web/20210720072326/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/DCA_SITREP%20July%2020.pdf ]

There has been a slow relaxation of restrictions across the country. Bans on gatherings do exist, but the wording of the government advice would suggest some leeway is permitted - the Government seems focused on preventing gatherings in cinemas, pools, religious centres etc. rather than simply a small number of people gathering.    [ https://web.archive.org/web/20210720072326/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/DCA_SITREP%20July%2020.pdf ]

Per a news article published on July 24th, Public transport bans have now been lifted however medical professionals still recommend that little public transport is undertaken. [ https://web.archive.org/web/20210725180140/https://kathmandupost.com/national/2021/07/24/ban-on-long-route-transport-lifted-amid-virus-concerns ]

By the 25th of July, lockdown measures should be lifted in full. In keeping with this, measures have been relaxed throughout the month of July, with restrictions primarily being placed on large potential gathering sites (Cinemas, pools etc.), with nothing being said of people staying at home.     [ https://web.archive.org/web/20210720223326/https://reliefweb.int/report/nepal/nepal-covid-19-response-situation-report-no-09-20-july-2021 ]

Despite some outrage from Nepalese medical professionals, long range public transport is now permitted in Nepal, allowing total freedom of movement between districts.    [ https://web.archive.org/web/20210725180140/https://kathmandupost.com/national/2021/07/24/ban-on-long-route-transport-lifted-amid-virus-concerns ]

Per information from the US embassy, entrants to the Kathmandu Valley are subject to a mandatory quarantine.    [ https://web.archive.org/web/20210725181046/https://np.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/ ]
Data suggests no change in policy since previous update    [ https://web.archive.org/web/20210725135655/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#N ]

Loan payments due in April and May are not being pursued until Mid-July. Equally, there has been a decrease in the interest rates on loan repayments. See below for further details:    [ https://web.archive.org/web/20210725135655/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#N ]

The Nepalese Ministry of Health is publishing constant covid-19 updates on their website. These updates seem sporadic in English, but seem far more constant in the native language.    [ https://web.archive.org/web/20210725182512/https://mohp.gov.np/en ]

All people can be tested at a handful of Nepalese hospitals, however the tests must be paid for in advance. Results are available within 72 hours of testing.    [ https://web.archive.org/web/20210725181046/https://np.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/ ]

A UNICEF report from the end of June 2021 suggests that whilst contact tracing is intended to be mobilised in Nepal, limited technology, data, and trained staff make it very difficult to implement. The contact tracing is best described as limited.    [ https://web.archive.org/web/20210725183038/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/UNICEF%20Nepal%20Humanitarian%20Situation%20Report%20No%202%20-%201%20Jan%20-%2030%20June%202021.pdf ]

The US embassy in Nepal suggests that a failure to wear a mask outside may lead to both arrest and a fine   [ https://web.archive.org/web/20210725181046/https://np.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/ ].      It is however worth noting that of July 25th, lockdown measures should have been relaxed in full, however there is no data regarding face mask requirements following this event  [ https://web.archive.org/web/20210720223326/https://reliefweb.int/report/nepal/nepal-covid-19-response-situation-report-no-09-20-july-2021 ]    Consideration should also be given to the fact that there was a street rally in the Kailali district on July 13th 2021, culminating in 150 people being given face masks and an education on why to use them. This would suggest that there is limited face mask use in many parts of Nepal, despite the strict requirements [ https://web.archive.org/web/20210720072326/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/DCA_SITREP%20July%2020.pdf ]

There does not seem to be a hard and fast rule regarding which groups are eligible for vaccination. Within a report linked below, the sentence "The crowds of people that have turned up to get the COVID-19 vaccines have not been well-managed in the vaccination   centers across Kathmandu Valley where the first dose of Vero Cell vaccine is being administered. The senior citizens in the   queue were unable to get the shot despite waiting for hours." indicates that parties are not being turned away for not belonging to any given group. Furthermore, the report also details the vaccination of 18 year olds in a rural part of Nepal per a Government program, alongside a focus on the vaccination of the elderly in "Dang" from mid-July onwards.     [ https://web.archive.org/web/20210719053246/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/Focused%20COVID-19_Media%20Monitoring_July%2019%2C%202021.pdf ]

There is no indication of specific measures in place to protect the elderly. It may be worth noting that there is an emphasis on vaccinating the elderly in Dang [ https://web.archive.org/web/20210719053246/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/Focused%20COVID-19_Media%20Monitoring_July%2019%2C%202021.pdf ]    Other than this, there is no indication that the elderly are subject to any restrictions other than the ordinary, as found here: [ https://web.archive.org/web/20210725181046/https://np.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/ ]

After nearly 18 months of very few tourists, Nepal has decided to reopen its borders to fully vaccinated travelers with no quarantine on arrival. Previously, visitors had to obtain special permission from Nepalese embassies and quarantine on arrival at their own expense for seven days. If tourists have received their final vaccination dose 14 days before arriving in Nepal, travelers can obtain a visa on arrival (which has stopped since March 2020) and won’t have to quarantine upon arrival.     However, partially vaccinated and unvaccinated travelers will have to obtain special visas from Nepalese embassies in their home countries. Plus, they will still have to undergo a 10-day quarantine in a government-approved hotel in Kathmandu. They’ll also need a PCR test before they go out and explore after undergoing the mandatory quarantine.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210927222521/https://www.traveloffpath.com/nepal-reopens-to-fully-vaccinated-travelers-without-restrictions/
